bibl.title: Letter from Wilbur A. Sawyer to Philip Showalter Hench, July 13, 1947

div1.p: Sawyer encloses a letter of introduction to Arthur Packard, an associate of Rockefeller's, for Hench. He describes plans to honor Reed by the American Society of Tropical Medicine, and thinks these efforts may increase interest in Hench's Camp Lazear project. Sawyer feels it is important to recognize Finlay's contributions, although he thinks scientists should not accept an “untenable interpretation” of certain Finlay experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Wilbur A. Sawyer to Philip Showalter Hench, July 13, 1947

opener.dateline:
3927??? Idaho Avenue, N.W., Washington, D.C.,
July 13, 1947

div1.p:
I have your letter of July 3d, 1947, and I am enclosing
a brief letter of introduction to Mr. Arthur W. Packard, who is an
associate of Mr. John D. Rockefeller, Jr., in matters of philanthropy.
He is doubtless the person you refer to in your letter. He is a fine person,
and I hope you will have the opportunity to meet him. He will remember me,
and it may be of advantage to enclose my letter with your first communication.

You probably know that Walter Reed was elected to the Hall of
Fame nearly two years ago. At long last it looks as though an attempt
is going to be made to raise the necessary $6000 or more which will be
the cost of the bust, pedestal, etc. The American Society of Tropical
Medicine is considering taking the lead in making the collections, and
it will be a reflection on the medical profession if it does not succeed
soon. We hope to hold a meeting in the Departmental Auditorium in
Washington next May during the Fourth International Congresses on Tropical Medicine and Malaria to celebrate the occasion of the unveiling of the statue
at about the same time in New York. This movement should increase the
interest in your project.

It is very important that Finlay should be recognized and honored
in your project as well as in our meeting, but that we scientific men should
make no move which might be interpreted as accepting an untenable interpretation
of certain of Finlay's published experiments. He was a great man and
deserves all the honors that are likely to be given him, and I hope you
will succeed in your effort.
